cosmology.name: The Great Wheel
cosmology.description: The default D&D cosmology includes more than two dozen planes. The most common understanding visualizes them as a group of concentric wheels, with the material realms at the center. The Inner Planes form a wheel around the Material Plane, enveloped in the Ethereal Plane. Then the Outer Planes form another wheel around that one, arranged according to alignment, with the Outlands linking them all.

alternateConfigurations.name: World Tree
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes situated among the roots and branches of a great cosmic tree (literally or figuratively)

alternateConfigurations.name: Vertical Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Material realms suspended between two other realities: the astral realms (the Astral Plane and the Outer Planes) above and the elemental realms (the Inner Planes) below

alternateConfigurations.name: Simplified Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: A cosmology with fewer planes: a Material Plane; the Transitive Planes; a single undifferentiated Elemental Plane; an Overheaven where good deities and Celestials dwell; and an Underworld where evil deities and Fiends reside

alternateConfigurations.name: Orbital Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes arranged in a complex system of orbits, with planes exerting greater influence on the Material Plane the closer they draw to it

planeCategories.name: Material Realms
planeCategories.description: Most D&D worlds are located on the Material Plane, which has two planar echoes: the Feywild and the Shadowfell.

planeCategories.name: Transitive Planes
planeCategories.description: The Ethereal Plane and the Astral Plane are boundless realms that provide passage between other planes of existence.

planeCategories.name: Inner Planes
planeCategories.description: The four Elemental Planes (Air, Earth, Fire, and Water), plus the Para-elemental Planes between them, are the Inner Planes.

planeCategories.name: Outer Planes
planeCategories.description: Seventeen Outer Planes correspond to the nine alignments and shades of philosophical difference between them.

planeCategories.name: Positive and Negative Planes
planeCategories.description: These two planes enfold the rest of the cosmology, providing the raw forces of life and death that underlie all existence in the multiverse.

planes.name: Arborea
planes.philosophicalEssence: Arborea is a plane of extremes, of violent moods and deep affections, of whim backed by steel, and of passions that blaze brightly until they burn out. Its good-natured inhabitants are dedicated to fighting evil, but their reckless emotions sometimes break free with devastating consequences. Rage is as common and as honored as joy in Arborea.
planes.emotionalInfluence: Creatures that visit Arborea and then leave sometimes experience a desperate desire to return—a yearning so intense that it can interfere with day-to-day life.

physicalProperties.atmosphereNotes: The air of Arborea seems charged with excitement. Sudden squalls brew up out of nowhere, beating the tree-lined paths with heavy winds. The storms pass within minutes and leave behind warm flares of sunlight filtering through the forest canopy. Music always seems to be playing in the distance.

temperature.description: Variable by layer: Arvandor is warm and lush, Aquallor features mighty storms over an eternal ocean, and Mithardir is a desert of white sand.

physicalProperties.weatherPatterns: Sudden squalls brew up out of nowhere, beating the tree-lined paths with heavy winds. The storms pass within minutes and leave behind warm flares of sunlight filtering through the forest canopy.

layers.name: Arvandor
layers.description: Towering trees, colorful wildflowers, abundant grain, and delicious fruit create a lush environment. The River Oceanus streams across this top layer of Arborea.
layers.environmentalDescription: Towering trees, colorful wildflowers, abundant grain, and delicious fruit create a lush environment. Stupendously craggy mountains, unbelievably deep gorges, forests of monstrously huge trees, and vast stretches of wheat fields, orchards, and arbors. Wild-hearted nature spirits dwell in every glade and stream. Groups of elf musicians play music that drifts through the forest.

layers.name: Aquallor
layers.description: An eternal ocean fed by the River Oceanus is home to teeming sea life and mighty storms. The River Oceanus drains away somewhere in this layer.
layers.environmentalDescription: An eternal ocean fed by the River Oceanus is home to teeming sea life and mighty storms.

layers.name: Mithardir
layers.description: A desert of white sand is abandoned by whatever powers once lived there.
layers.environmentalDescription: A desert of white sand is abandoned by whatever powers once lived there. What secrets lie buried in the sands of Mithardir is unknown. An expedition might involve investigating whatever gods or Celestials once inhabited the silver desert or find some knowledge they possessed.

timeFlow.description: No special time flow rules are specified for Arborea. Distance is virtually meaningless on the Outer Planes; a perceptible region might seem quite small on one visit, and on another trip can stretch on to what seems like infinity.

environmentalEffects.name: Emotional Honesty and Unfettered Emotion
environmentalEffects.description: An adventure in Arborea can be an opportunity for characters to discover who they are when masks fall away and the honesty of unfettered emotion is revealed. Lifelong friends might share a laugh over food and wine, cross blades over a mutual lover, and write songs celebrating each other's courage and integrity, all in a single evening.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: No specific saving throw or mechanical effect is defined in the 2024 rules. The DM may use this as a roleplaying guide and award Heroic Inspiration to characters who bring these emotional characteristics to life.
environmentalEffects.emotionalEffect: Violent moods, deep affections, passions that blaze brightly until they burn out. Rage is as common and as honored as joy.

environmentalEffects.name: Desperate Desire to Return
environmentalEffects.description: Creatures that visit Arborea and then leave sometimes experience a desperate desire to return—a yearning so intense that it can interfere with day-to-day life.
environmentalEffects.mechanicalEffect: No specific saving throw or DC is defined. This is described as a narrative effect that can interfere with day-to-day life after leaving the plane.
environmentalEffects.emotionalEffect: A desperate desire to return to Arborea—a yearning so intense that it can interfere with day-to-day life.

planarConnections.name: River Oceanus
planarConnections.description: The River Oceanus streams across the top layer of Arborea (Arvandor) and finally drains away somewhere in Arborea's second layer (Aquallor). The water of the Oceanus is sweet and fragrant, as befits its headwaters in the Blessed Fields of Elysium. Trading vessels sail up and down its length, and small towns line its banks. Travelers can usually find a boat to hire somewhere along its shores.

civilizations.name: Elf musicians
civilizations.description: Groups of elf musicians play music that drifts through the forests of Arvandor.

civilizations.name: Wild-hearted nature spirits
civilizations.description: Wild-hearted nature spirits dwell in every glade and stream, brooking no infringement.

savingThrow.triggerDescription: After finishing a Long Rest on Arborea, a Fiend makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw.

onFailure.description: Whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save.
onFailure.cumulativeDescription: The d4 subtraction effect is cumulative with each failed save.

onSuccess.description: The creature is not further affected by planar dissonance this rest period.

recoveryMethods: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to the creature's nature ends all cumulative effects

planarDissonance.description: Fiends who visit Arborea (an Upper Plane) experience significant discomfort if their visits last more than a few hours. After finishing a Long Rest on Arborea, a Fiend makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save and ends when the creature finishes a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to its nature.

domainsOrRegions.name: Sylvania
domainsOrRegions.description: Sylvania is the gate-town in the Outlands that contains a portal leading to Arborea. Each gate-town shares many of the characteristics of the plane where its gate leads.

adventureThemes: Discovering who you are when masks fall away and the honesty of unfettered emotion is revealed
Emotional honesty leading to hurt feelings and lingering resentment for those unaccustomed to candor
Investigating the abandoned desert of Mithardir and the secrets of whatever gods or Celestials once inhabited it
Dealing with the desperate yearning to return after leaving

globalPlanarConnections.name: River Oceanus
globalPlanarConnections.description: The water of the Oceanus is sweet and fragrant, as befits its headwaters in the Blessed Fields of Elysium. This plane-spanning waterway provides a path through some of the Upper Planes. It flows through each of Elysium's layers, passes through the top layer of the Beastlands, streams across the top layer of Arborea, and finally drains away somewhere in Arborea's second layer. Trading vessels sail up and down its length, and small towns line its banks. Travelers can usually find a boat to hire somewhere along its shores.

globalPlanarConnections.name: Infinite Staircase
globalPlanarConnections.description: The Infinite Staircase is an extradimensional staircase that connects the planes. An entrance usually appears as a nondescript door. Beyond the portal lies a small landing with a stairway leading up and down. Doors to the Infinite Staircase are often tucked away in dusty, half-forgotten places.

globalPlanarConnections.name: Yggdrasil, the World Tree
globalPlanarConnections.description: The World Tree, Yggdrasil, is a cosmic ash tree that spans the Outer Planes and links them to many worlds of the Material Plane. Its roots stretch into the Lower Planes, touching Hades, Pandemonium, and possibly other Lower Planes. Most of its massive trunk rises through the plane of Ysgard, and its branches stretch through the Upper Planes and across the Astral to the Material Plane.

planarTravelMethods.name: Planar Portals
planarTravelMethods.description: A portal is a stationary, interplanar connection that links a specific location on one plane to a specific location on another. Some portals function like doorways, others are locations that exist on multiple planes at once or flicker from one plane to another. Some are vortices joining planes with similar locations.
requirements: Finding a portal that leads to the desired destination
Meeting the portal's requirements (command, key item, random, situation, or time)
risks: Most portals aren't open all the time

planarTravelMethods.name: Spells
planarTravelMethods.description: A number of spells allow direct or indirect access to different planes of existence.
requirements: Ability to cast the relevant spell

planarTravelMethods.name: Astral Color Pools
planarTravelMethods.description: Gateways leading from the Astral Plane to other planes appear as two-dimensional pools of rippling colors, 1d6 × 10 feet in diameter. The Astral color pool leading to Arborea is sapphire blue.

planarAdventureSituations.situation: When magic fails to revive a dead person, the only solution is to venture to the Outer Planes to find the person's spirit and either release it from some prison or convince the person to return to life.

People who venture into the woods keep accidentally wandering into the Feywild or the Shadowfell. They might never return, return with no sense of how much time has passed, or return dramatically changed.
A long-dead oracle is the only one who knows how a terrible prophecy might be averted, but the cataclysmic fulfillment of the prophecy has already begun.
A god has stopped answering prayers and won't respond to any Commune spell.
A devil has tricked an angel into meddling in the Blood War, and the angel seeks mortal aid.
An ancestor of one of the characters must be convinced to bless the character before the full power of the character's bloodline can be unleashed.
A foolhardy knight carried a holy weapon on a doomed mission into the Nine Hells, and the powers of Mount Celestia want the weapon and the knight's remains retrieved.
A titan is imprisoned on an Outer Plane. The characters might be trying to stop those who seek to release it, or they might want to release it to help defend the world from a greater threat.

To prove themselves worthy of an even greater quest, the characters are sent to slay a horrible monster, win the favor of a powerful planar being, negotiate peace between two warring planar factions, or retrieve a long-lost item on another plane.
An item of legend is being sold at auction in Sigil, the City of Brass, or some other planar metropolis.

globalPlanarDissonance.description: Celestials who visit the Lower Planes and Fiends who visit the Upper Planes experience significant discomfort if their visits last more than a few hours. After finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is alien to its nature, a Celestial or Fiend makes a DC 10 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save and ends when the creature finishes a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to its nature.

savingThrow.triggerDescription: After finishing a Long Rest on a plane that is alien to the creature's nature.

onFailure.description: Whenever the creature makes a D20 Test, the creature must subtract 1d4 from the roll. The effect is cumulative with each failed save.
onFailure.cumulativeDescription: Each failed save adds another 1d4 subtracted from D20 Tests, cumulative with previous failures.

onSuccess.description: The creature is not further affected by planar dissonance for this rest period.

recoveryMethods: Finishing a Long Rest on a plane that isn't opposed to the creature's nature ends all cumulative effects

savingThrowProbabilities.formula: P(fail | modifier m) = max(0.05, min(0.95, (DC - 1 - m) / 20))
